document.title: Bottled Waters with and Without PFAS
document.description: A list of bottled waters that contain PFAS and those that do not.

body.raw: ## Introduction If you haven't heard, PFAS (per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances) are a group of compounds that are commonly found in drinking water. These compounds are known to be harmful to human health and have been linked to various health issues, including cancer, thyroid disease, and immune system disorders. Unfortunately, PFAS are not only found in drinking water but also in many consumer products, including food packaging, non-stick cookware, and even some cosmetics. Over the last few years, there has been a growing concern about the presence of PFAS in bottled water, with many consumers wondering which brands are safe to drink. Here's a most of up to date list of bottled waters that contain PFAS and those that do not. Note most brands do not test for PFAS so some of this data be out of date. Oasis is working on going through each one and testing them for PFAS in our lab, we will update this list as we get more data. ## Bottled Waters with PFAS Consumer Reports tested 47 bottled waters and found that 43 of them contained detectable levels of PFAS. [Another study](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0043135421004905?dgcid=rss_sd_all) by led by Johns Hopkins University researchers, detected PFAS substances in 39 out of more than 100 bottled waters tested. Even more recenlty the EPA announced at least 33% of water systems tested contained PFAS. Here's what the latest reports say: ### PFAS between 0 and 1 ppt - 365 Everyday Value (Whole Foods) Spring Water - Absopure Purified Water - Alkaline88 Natural Alkaline Water - Aquafina Natural Purified Water - Core Hydration Natural Enhanced Water - Crystal Geyser Natural Spring Water - Dasani Natural Purified Water - Essentia Natural Purified Alkaline Water - Evian Natural Spring Water - Fiji Water Natural Artesian Water - Flow Alkaline Spring Water - Great Value (Walmart) Natural Purified Water - Ice Mountain Natural Spring Water - Just 100% Spring Water - Just The Basics (CVS) Purified Water - Kirkland Signature (Costco Purified Water) - LifeWtr Natural Purified Water - Liquid Death Spring Water - Nestlé Pure Life Natural Purified Water - Niagara Natural Purified Water - Ozarka Natural Spring Water - Pathwater Purified Water - Penta Ultra Pure Water - Poland Spring Natural Spring Water - Saratoga Natural Spring Water - Smartwater Natural Enhanced Water - Trader Joe’s Alkaline Water + Electrolytes - Zephyrhills Natural Spring Water - Spindrift - Sanpellegrino - Dasani - Schweppes - Prime ### PFAS over 1 ppt - Deer Park: 1.21 - Tourmaline Spring: 4.64 - Topo Chico: 3.9 - Perrier: 1.1 - La Croix: 1.16 - Canada dry: 1.24 - Poland Spring carbonated: 1.66 - Bubly 2.24 - Polar 6.41 ## Bottled Waters without PFAS - Arrowhead Spring water - Boxed Water - Waiakea Hawaiian Volcanic Water - Good & Gather (Target) Purified Water [This report](https://dec.vermont.gov/sites/dec/files/documents/VT%20Bottled%20Water%20Non-Detect%20PFAS%20Results_0.pdf) lists many other brands as without PFAS but we have not veried this information. ## Conclusion The fact is most brands don't test for PFAS and or don't share these reports so it's difficult to know for sure which waters don't contain PFAS without testing each one. As mentioned this is something we are working on and will update this list as we get more data. ## References https://www.consumerreports.org/water-quality/whats-really-in-your-bottled-water-a5361150329/#:~:text=Consumer%20Reports%20found%20toxic%20PFAS,water%20brands%2C%20especially%20carbonated%20ones&text=CR%20recently%20tested%2047%20bottled,noncarbonated%20and%2012%20carbonated%20ones https://www.ewg.org/news-insights/news-release/2024/02/epa-reveals-more-evidence-widespread-forever-chemicals-drinking https://www.consumerreports.org/health/bottled-water/pfas-in-bottled-water-new-study-finds-a1111233122/

document.title: How our Scoring Works
document.description: Formula behind the Oasis scoring system

body.raw: ## Table of Contents - [Overview](#overview) - [How we score bottled water](#how-we-score-bottled-water) - [How we score tap water](#how-we-score-tap-water) - [How we score filters](#how-we-score-filters) ## Overview We all need water, but not all water is the same. Whether it's bottled, straight from the tap, or filtered, understanding the cleanliness and health of water is vital for taking care of our health and supporting longevity. Every water has it's own unique characteristics and we've created a scoring system to help you understand the quality of the water you drink. Please note our scoring system is subject to change in light of new scientific evidence and research. We choose to open-source our scoring system to allow for transparency and to encourage feedback and improvement. # How we score bottled water Everything is scored out of 100 and we penalize each item depending on a few factors. Factors we consider: - Source - Contaminant amount and levels - PFAS - Packaging/material - Filtration method - PH ### Source The source of water is the first thing we consider when scoring water. Not all water is the same and it starts with the source. A large portion of bottled water comes straight from municipal water supplies and undergoes intense treatement to remove the countless toxins inside. This treatment strips water of it's natural minerals making it harder for the body to digest and often adds disenfenctant by-products to the water. Other source of water include natural springs, aquifers, icebergs, deep wells, and other natural sources. Ideally the water doesn't need to be filtered much and comes from a natural source which includes healthy minerals. Penalties - Municipal water supply: 30 - Mountain spring: +10 (bonus) - Unknown (not stated in report): 5 - Well: 0 ### Contaminant amount and levels It's hard to find water on Earth anymore without some level of contamination, however we set a high standard and believe water can only be 100/100 if it has no harmful contmainants. We penalize water for the number of unique contaminants and the levels of each substance (based on the legal limit or health guideline). Penalties: - Unique contaminants: 5 per contaminant (max 40) - Amount over guideline: level above \* 2.5 (max 40) If there is no lab report we dock the item 50 points to account for the unknown contaminants. ### PFAS Levels PFAS satnd for per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances and are known as "forever chemicals" because they do not break down in the environment. They are found in many consumer products and have been linked to various health issues, including cancer, thyroid disease, and immune system disorders. Many brands don't test for PFAS so we penalize 10 points for not testing. If there are detected PFAS, we dock a 10 point penalty along with the associated contaminant penalties which depend on the exact PFAS and amounts of each detected. ### Packaging/material More and more studies are showing the dangers of plastic and the microplastics that leach into the water. We penalize water bottles made of plastic. Penalties: - Plastic: 20 ### Filtration method There are several ways to filter water and some filtering techniques can strip water of it's natural minerals which provide our body with essential nutrients. Often a more agressive filtration method such as distillation is a reflection of how dirty the source water is. Penalties: - Distillation: 10 ### PH There are several studies showing the ability of alkline water to aide the body in normalizing your PH levels. This essentially means that alkline water can help you maintain a healthy PH level in your body especially if you eat processed foods or drink a lot of alcohol. We award 5 point bonus if the water as a ph between 8 and 9. We penalize waters that are too acidic and dock 15 points. # How we score tap water Tap water is popularly known as a commodity that is safe to drink and available to everyone. However, the quality of tap water can vary greatly depending on where you live and over the years has become increasingly polluted. Each city in the United States is usually supplied by one or more water utlities and we analyze the water from each utility. When analyzing tap water, we consider the following factors: - Unique contaminants - Levels of each substance ### Unique contaminants Our database includes all known toxins that can be present in water. We consider anything that isn't beneficial to the body as a contaminant. Penalties: - Unique contaminants: 3.5 per contaminant ### Levels of each substance Not only is the presence of a contaminant important, but the levels of each substance are also crucial. We penalize water for the amount of each substance over the health or legal guideline. Penalties: - Amount over guideline: multiple above / 5 # How we score filters As earth's water becomes more and more polluted, the need for water filters has increased. There are many different types of filters and often it isn't clear which filter is best. Factors we consider: - Number of common contaminants removed - Number of uncommong contamianants remove We weight common contaminants 5 times higher than uncommon contaminants. ### Common contaminants We maintain a list of common contaminants often found in bottled and tap water. These include - Bromide - Sulfate - Total Trihalomethanes - Gross Alpha Particle Activity - Arsenic - Barium - Fluoride - Nitrate - Uranium - Bromodichloromethane - Chloroform - Dibromochloromethane - Radon - Chloramine - Haloacetic Acids (HAA9) - Haloacetic Acids (HAA5) - Chromium (hexavalent) - Nitrite - Bromate - Bromoform - Dibromoacetic Acid - Dichloroacetic Acid - Chlorine - Lead - Mercury - 1,4-Dioxane - Bromochloroacetic acid - Beryllium - Antimony - Selenium - 1,2,3-Trichloropropane - PFAS/PFOS - Bromodichloroacetic acid - Radium 226 and 228 - Microplastics We take the percentage of common contaminants removed to total common contaminants. ### Uncommon contaminants There are many more contaminants that could possibly be in your drinking water but are much more rare. There are 100s of them so we aren't going to list them all here but you can find the full list on each filter page. ## References https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/magazine/magazine_article/fluoridated-drinking-water/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6195894/ https://www.cdc.gov/fluoridation/statistics/cost.htm https://bmcoralhealth.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s12903-018-0684-2 https://www.newsweek.com/fluoridation-may-not-prevent-cavities-huge-study-shows-348251 https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2666911021000216

document.title: Is Flouride in Drinking Water Safe?

body.raw:
## Historical background Hailing from the innovative strides of the early 20th century, fluoride made its grand entrance as a dental health game-changer. Fast forward to the mid-1940s, and it's a mainstay in our nation's crusade against cavities, earning accolades as a triumph in public health. Today, this cavity combatant finds its way into the taps of roughly 75% of American homes. Our water is fortified with various forms of fluoride, from fluorosilicic acid to sodium fluorosilicate, and sodium fluoride, ensuring that every sip comes with a shield against tooth decay. While our natural water bodies like lakes and rivers boast an average fluoride concentration of about 0.2 mg/L, the levels can vary, painting a diverse fluoride landscape across the U.S.
This naturally occurring mineral, lauded for its cavity-fighting abilities, has been a subject of continuous scientific scrutiny. ## Regulation of flouride in drinking water? Since 1962, the United States Public Health Service (PHS) has recommended fluoride concentrations in public water supplies to be maintained between 0.7 and 1.2 mg/L to aid in the prevention of dental cavities. In 2015, this recommendation was adjusted to a single target of 0.7 mg/L of fluoride. This update reflects the increased availability of fluoride from various sources, such as toothpaste, requiring a reassessment to avoid excessive intake. The EPA caps fluoride in public drinking water at 4.0 mg/L. Prolonged exposure above this limit risks skeletal fluorosis, causing joint pain and potential bone weakness or fractures in seniors. To safeguard our kids from dental fluorosis, the EPA recommends capping fluoride levels at 2.0 mg/L. This helps prevent too much fluoride from disrupting normal tooth enamel formation in young smiles. Ensuring the purity of our bottled water, the FDA permits up to 2.4 mg/L of fluoride in non-fluoridated varieties, adapted to colder regions. For those with added fluoride, the cap is set at 0.7 mg/L, aligning with PHS guidelines. According to recent CDC guidelines, the fluoride content in children's toothpaste may be higher than recommended, especially when used in conjunction with fluoridated water. Parents are advised to monitor and manage their children's fluoride intake to prevent possible dental fluorosis, marked by changes in tooth enamel coloration. Moreover, new research indicates that fluoride's role in preventing tooth decay is significantly more impactful during childhood than in adulthood. Hence, the timing of fluoride consumption is crucial for its effectiveness in dental health. ## Possible risks of flouride in drinking water Elevated fluoride intake has been observed to alter tooth enamel, a condition known as dental fluorosis, and may contribute to bone fragility. Emerging studies raise concerns about fluoride's potential neurotoxicity, hinting at a link between high fluoride exposure and cognitive challenges.
**Bone Health Alert**: Persistent fluoride consumption can result in skeletal fluorosis, marked by bone accumulation of fluoride, leading to joint discomfort and increased risk of bone fractures among seniors. **Glandular Impact**: Research indicates fluoride accumulation in the pineal and thyroid glands, possibly disrupting their normal functions. **Tooth Discoloration**: High fluoride levels during teeth development in children can lead to dental fluorosis, noticeable through discolored tooth enamel. **Fluoride Toxicity**: Elevated fluoride levels, often from water sources or supplements, have been associated with a spectrum of health issues. **Additional Health** Implications: Indications of fluoride’s low-dose effects include potential harm to the nervous system, kidneys, and other health aspects: - Neurological Concerns: Fluoride exposure may be correlated with neurological alterations, particularly affecting children's cognitive development. - Kidney Health: Fluoridation at high levels could adversely impact renal function, as kidneys are pivotal in fluoride excretion. - Broader Health Impact: A comprehensive view of fluoride intake reveals possible influences on thyroid health, skeletal integrity, and reproductive health. **Fracture Risk Analysis**: Some evidence suggests that fluoride treatments aimed at countering osteoporosis may not decrease, and could potentially increase, the risk of nonvertebral fractures. Harvard's adjunct professor of environmental health, Philippe Grandjean, acknowledges fluoride's dental benefits but urges caution with its addition to water supplies. He advocates for precise dosing, awareness of its health implications, and attention to sensitive groups, such as infants and dialysis patients, who may require lower fluoride exposure. ## Other sources of flouride
## Conclusion With the ongoing research surrounding flouride most experts agree to limit the amount of flouride consumed and choose topical solutions like toothpaste to get the benefits of flouride. ## References https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/magazine/magazine_article/fluoridated-drinking-water/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6195894/ https://www.cdc.gov/fluoridation/statistics/cost.htm https://bmcoralhealth.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s12903-018-0684-2 https://www.newsweek.com/fluoridation-may-not-prevent-cavities-huge-study-shows-348251 https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2666911021000216

`,(0,t.jsxDEV)(a.p,{children:`Hailing from the innovative strides of the early 20th century, fluoride made its grand entrance as a dental health game-changer.
Fast forward to the mid-1940s, and it's a mainstay in our nation's crusade against cavities, earning accolades as a triumph in
public health. Today, this cavity combatant finds its way into the taps of roughly 75% of American homes.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oasis/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-39ee429a-c208-4c14-881e-a27db3dea0df.mdx",lineNumber:19,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,t.jsxDEV)(a.p,{children:`Our water is fortified with various forms of fluoride, from fluorosilicic acid to sodium fluorosilicate, and sodium fluoride,
ensuring that every sip comes with a shield against tooth decay. While our natural water bodies like lakes and rivers boast an
average fluoride concentration of about 0.2 mg/L, the levels can vary, painting a diverse fluoride landscape across the U.S.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oasis/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-39ee429a-c208-4c14-881e-a27db3dea0df.mdx",lineNumber:23,columnNumber:1},this),`

`,(0,t.jsxDEV)(a.h2,{children:"Regulation of flouride in drinking water?"},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oasis/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-39ee429a-c208-4c14-881e-a27db3dea0df.mdx",lineNumber:46,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,t.jsxDEV)(a.p,{children:`Since 1962, the United States Public Health Service (PHS) has recommended fluoride concentrations in public water supplies
to be maintained between 0.7 and 1.2 mg/L to aid in the prevention of dental cavities. In 2015,
this recommendation was adjusted to a single target of 0.7 mg/L of fluoride. This update reflects the
increased availability of fluoride from various sources, such as toothpaste, requiring a reassessment to avoid excessive intake.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oasis/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-39ee429a-c208-4c14-881e-a27db3dea0df.mdx",lineNumber:48,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,t.jsxDEV)(a.p,{children:`The EPA caps fluoride in public drinking water at 4.0 mg/L. Prolonged exposure above this limit risks skeletal fluorosis,
causing joint pain and potential bone weakness or fractures in seniors.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oasis/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-39ee429a-c208-4c14-881e-a27db3dea0df.mdx",lineNumber:53,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,t.jsxDEV)(a.p,{children:`To safeguard our kids from dental fluorosis, the EPA recommends capping fluoride levels at 2.0 mg/L.
This helps prevent too much fluoride from disrupting normal tooth enamel formation in young smiles.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oasis/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-39ee429a-c208-4c14-881e-a27db3dea0df.mdx",lineNumber:56,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,t.jsxDEV)(a.p,{children:`Ensuring the purity of our bottled water, the FDA permits up to 2.4 mg/L of fluoride in non-fluoridated varieties,
adapted to colder regions. For those with added fluoride, the cap is set at 0.7 mg/L, aligning with PHS guidelines.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oasis/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-39ee429a-c208-4c14-881e-a27db3dea0df.mdx",lineNumber:59,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,t.jsxDEV)(a.p,{children:`According to recent CDC guidelines, the fluoride content in children's toothpaste may be higher than recommended, especially when
used in conjunction with fluoridated water. Parents are advised to monitor and manage their children's fluoride intake to prevent
possible dental fluorosis, marked by changes in tooth enamel coloration.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oasis/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-39ee429a-c208-4c14-881e-a27db3dea0df.mdx",lineNumber:62,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,t.jsxDEV)(a.p,{children:`Moreover, new research indicates that fluoride's role in preventing tooth decay is significantly more impactful during
childhood than in adulthood.
